Award.AwardTitle: The interplay between electron and energy transfer in molecular nanosystems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abraham Nitzan of the University of Pennsylvania is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry. They are supported to develop a conceptual framework and computational methodologies to address energy conversion processes on the nano scale. Energy conversion - the change from one form of available energy to another, has always been an important subject for fundamental research as well as technological applications. Scientists and engineers strive to increase the efficiency of converting energy to useful forms on one hand, and to limit its escape as wasted forms on the other. As science and technology enter the nano age, such problems re-emerge in new forms that require new conceptual frameworks and new experimental and computational approaches for their description. Nitzan and his coworkers focus on several central issues within this effort: The description of heat transfer on the molecular scale and the coupling between charge and heat transport in molecular systems. They are constructing a quantum thermodynamics framework to address such processes, their inter-relationships and their efficiencies. The research impacts a diverse range of applications of nanoscience -- from dissipation and information loss in quantum computing to the efficiency of operation of nano-photo-devices as well as biological electron-transfer processes. The Nitzan group provides research opportunities for students at all levels: high school, undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral.


This project addresses three major problems: 1) electron transfer across thermal gradients. Although coupling between electron and energy transfer in metals is known to exist, it is usually disregarded in models of electron hopping in molecular systems and often overlooked even in semiconductors. The objective is to study the interplay between electron and heat transport in such systems, to propose ways for their experimental observation, and to examine their implications for nanoscale energy conversion devices. 2) heat transfer on the molecular scale, where the connection between structural and dynamical properties of molecules and their ability to conduct, utilize and dissipate heat is being examined. Here the proposed investigation contacts the growing number of experimental groups working in this area as well as with other computational investigations. 3) Finally, this project continues work in the Nitzan group aimed at developing a general framework for the description of such process within a quantum generalization of thermodynamics of small systems. This work aims to achieve the equivalent of what classical thermodynamics does on the macroscopic scale: to provide concepts, theoretical structure and computational methodologies for addressing processes underlying energy conversion, dissipation and utilization that occur on the molecular scale where quantum mechanics is strongly manifested. The processes studied in the first two parts of the project will be formulated in this language as special cases of what should become a quantum thermodynamics theory of nanoscale systems that strongly interact with their environment.

PI: Abraham Nitzan, University of Pennsylvania

Title: The interplay between electron and energy transfer in molecular nanosystems

Award Number: 1665291

Award Ends:07/31/2020

Project Outcomes Report

How do well known and well understood macroscopic chemical and physical processes appear in the nano-world? Such questions have underlined research in nanosize systems for several decades now. These is no unique answer, as different phenomena reveal different manifestations of system size, however there are general guiding principles that emerge from considerations of characteristic length and time-scales associated with the process under study and the system size. Studies of such phenomena stand at the core of recent and ongoing developments in the new field of nanotechnology.

The research project "Interplay between electron and energy transfer in molecular nanosystems: Dynamics and thermodynamics" has focused on several fundamental questions pertaining to this general subject: (a) Developing numerical codes for evaluating heat transport through molecular junctions and use the resulting numerical methodology to study the relationship between molecular type and structure and its heat conduction properties. (b) Considering that in nanosize systems undergoing non-equilibrium processes, temperature is not necessarily uniform over the system, and keeping in mind technological advances in the ability to detect and control temperature on the nanoscale, we have set to develop a theoretical framework to describe an important and much studied class of chemical phenomena-electron transfer processes - in situations characterized by significantly non-uniform thermal landscape. (c) To develop a thermodynamic framework for analyzing energy conversion processes on the nanoscale. On this size scale the old science of thermodynamics assumes new characteristics: First, fluctuations become as important as averaged quantities, and second, quantum phenomena may affect and sometime dominate the thermodynamic processes, thereby requiring quantum considerations in the thermodynamic analysis.

During the lifetime of this project we have achieved most of our goals on parts (a) and (b) above. In particular, our heat transport code has been developed up to a stage where practical applications can be performed in routine ways, and is now available in the public domain. We have used it to investigate structure-function interrelations regarding heat conduction by several common organic molecules, comparing the performance of classical-mechanics calculation in comparison with their quantum parallels. Of particular interest is the observation that interference between different heat conduction pathways, that sometime dominate the heat transport behavior and are usually considered to be of quantum origin, are seen also in the classical calculation.

In investigating chemical processes in systems with non-homogeneous temperature distribution on the nanoscale, we have focused on an important class of phenomena-electron transfer processes. Such processes lie at the core of many physical, chemical and biological phenomena, including photosynthesis, vision, corrosion and battery operation. The theoretical understanding of such processes is well developed for systems characterized by a single uniform temperature. We have now extended this theory to systems with non-uniform temperature distributions, for example when the donor and acceptor sites of the electron transfer process are positioned in environments of different temperatures. Our theory makes definite predictions for processes that can now be realistically realized in the laboratory, and indicates the possibility for constructing interesting devices (e.g. electrical and thermoelectrical molecular scale rectifiers) based on this phenomenon.

Part (c) of our project is an ongoing process, part of a universal effort to understand thermodynamics of nanosystems and in particular the implications of quantum mechanics on energy conversion processes in such systems. In our work we have focused on systems based on molecular conduction junctions, and developed methodologies for computing and analyzing the interplay of electrical, chemical and mechanical energies in such systems. Besides working on several theoretical models, we have developed a numerical methodology for simulating such phenomena, which makes it possible to address situations beyond simple model assumptions. An important extension of our work, currently under development, is to include optical processes in such quantum thermodynamic considerations.

Out work has resulted in over 20 publications in the scientific literature and has been presented in many scientific conferences. It has also been recognized by the 2019 Earle K. Plyler Prize for Molecular Spectroscopy & Dynamics given by the American Physical Society and the 2020 ACS (American Chemical Society) Award in Theoretical Chemistry.
